---
Observation: Multiple login attempts were seen from the same source.
Outcome: Some logins succeeded.
Unknown: Whether the logins were authorized.
---

Multiple login attempts were observed from the same source, and some of those attempts resulted in successful logins. This indicates that access was obtained after repeated attempts.

At this time, it is not yet determined whether the successful logins were authorized. Without that confirmation, the situation should be treated as a potential unauthorized access event until proven otherwise.

Next steps depend on validating whether the activity aligns with expected use. If authorization cannot be confirmed, the incident should be documented, and additional investigation should focus on identifying what was accessed after the successful logins.

Finding: A configuration change was deployed without prior approval.
Evidence: Change record is missing.
Unknown: Whether the change caused customer impact.
---

A configuration change was deployed without prior approval, and the supporting change record is missing. This represents a breakdown in the expected change control process.

It is not yet determined whether this change caused customer impact. Because the change was not formally recorded, assessing intent and scope requires additional investigation.

To reduce recurrence, the missing record should be addressed and the approval process should be reinforced so that future deployments have an auditable trail. Any customer impact, if confirmed, should be documented along with remediation actions.

Event: Backups were not performed for one week.
Unknown: Why backups did not run.
Unknown: Whether any restore tests are affected.
---

Backups were not performed for one week, creating a gap in recovery coverage for that period. This increases risk that recent data or state changes cannot be restored if needed.

The reason the backups did not run is not yet determined. It is also not yet determined whether any restore tests are affected by the missing backup window.

The situation should be documented and investigated to identify the cause of the missed backups and to validate restore readiness going forward.

Observation: An alert fired repeatedly.
Action taken: Alert was muted temporarily.
Unknown: Whether the underlying condition persists.
---

An alert fired repeatedly, and it was muted temporarily as an operational response. While this reduced immediate noise, it may also reduce visibility if the condition continues.

It is not yet determined whether the underlying condition persists. Without confirming the root cause, the risk is that the triggering condition remains active while detection has been reduced.

The alert mute should be time-bounded and paired with investigation to confirm whether the triggering condition has been resolved or is still present.

Unknown: Who owns the procedure.
Unknown: When it will be completed.
---

Several items in a procedure are marked as 'TBD', indicating incomplete definition of operational steps. This creates execution risk because operators may not have clear instructions when the procedure is needed.

It is not yet determined who owns the procedure or when the missing sections will be completed. Without clear ownership and completion timing, the procedure may remain incomplete for an extended period.

The procedure should be reviewed to assign ownership and to define a completion plan for the remaining TBD sections so that it can be relied upon during operations.

Observation: A periodic review did not occur.
Evidence: No review notes were found.
Unknown: Whether the review was performed but not recorded.
---

A periodic review did not have supporting evidence, and no review notes were found. This suggests the review may not have occurred, or it may have been performed without being recorded.

It is not yet determined whether the review happened but was not documented. Either case creates risk: the control may be ineffective if not performed, or it may be non-auditable if not recorded.

The gap should be investigated and, if the review was performed, evidence should be captured. If it was not performed, a remediation plan should be documented to restore the expected review process.

The duration of the outage is not yet determined, and the cause is also not yet determined based on the provided information. Without these details, it is difficult to assess severity or recurrence likelihood.

The event should be documented with outage duration and cause once identified, and follow-up actions should focus on preventing recurrence.

---

A set of records was deleted, which can create operational and investigative risk depending on what was removed and whether it was recoverable.

It is not yet determined who performed the deletion or whether it was intended. Without this information, it is unclear whether the deletion represents a normal action or an error.

The deletion should be documented and investigated to confirm intent and actor. If the deletion was unintended, remediation should focus on recovery where possible and preventing similar deletions in the future.
